text: Department of the Treasury Internal Revenue Service
Section Title change to Wireless and Mobile Device Security Policy. Previous title was, Government Furnished and Personally Owned Mobile Device Security Policy
This policy has been updated to revise and incorporate requirements for government furnished mobile devices and non
government furnished/personally owned mobile devices that access, process, transmit, or store IRS information, in support of the Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) program.

This policy has been updated to revise and incorporate requirements for government furnished mobile devices and non-government furnished/personally owned mobile devices that access, process, transmit, or store IRS information, in support of the Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) program.

Several requirements from obsolesced Defense Information Systems Agency (DISA) Security Technical Implementation Guides (STIGs) have been removed, relocated to the appropriate Security Control Exhibits or IRM, or replaced where technically feasible.
Incorporated Interim Guidance (IG) Memo IT-10-0821-0007 - “ Peripheral Devices ”. This IG Memo consolidated several Bluetooth encryption controls in IRM 10.8.26.

Incorporated IG Memo IT-10-0820-0020 - “ Security Requirement Checklists ”. This IG Memo updates the IRM’s Scope, Security Requirements Checklists, and References Exhibits for the implementation of the Continuous Baseline process for updating checklists.
The following sections have been updated/clariﬁed with this version of policy:

EFFECT ON OTHER DOCUMENTS

IRM 10.8.26 dated July 21, 2020, is superseded. This IRM supersedes all prior versions of IRM 10.8.26, and supplements: IRM 10.8.1, IT Security, Policy and Guidance and IRM 10.8.2, IT Security, IT Security Roles and Responsibilities . This IRM obsoletes IG Memo, IT-10-0821-0007 - “ Peripheral Devices ” and IG Memo, IT-10- 0820-0020 - “ Security Requirement Checklists ”
AUDIENCE

IRM 10.8.26 applies to and shall be distributed to all employees, contractors, vendors, and volunteers responsible for ensuring the security of government furnished mobile devices and approved non-government furnished/personally owned (BYOD) mobile devices.

) This Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) lays the foundation to implement and manage security controls and guidance for government furnished mobile devices and non-government furnished/personally owned mobile devices that have been approved for use by employees participating in the Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) program, and the data stored on them, within the Internal Revenue Service (IRS). (

) Purpose of the Program : Develop and publish policies to protect the IRS against potential Information Technology (IT) threats and vulnerabilities and ensure compliance with federal mandates and legislation. (

) Audience : The provisions in this manual apply to: a. All offices and business, operating, and functional units within the IRS. b. Individuals and organizations having contractual arrangements with the IRS, including employees, contractors, vendors, volunteers and outsourc- ing providers, who use or operate information systems or mobile devices that store, process, or transmit IRS information or connect to an IRS network or system. Note: When the terms “mobile devices” and “mobile device users” are used within this IRM, they refer to both government furnished and approved non-government furnished/personally owned mobile devices and users unless otherwise noted. c. Bring Your Own Device (BYOD) participants, unless otherwise speciﬁed as only government furnished mobile devices. d. Government furnished or approved non-government furnished/personally owned mobile devices used to accomplish the IRS mission. Note: For the purpose of this IRM, laptops are categorized as a mobile device with computing and communication (e.g., wireless, local area network (LAN)) capability, and shall comply with all IRM
, Treasury Directive Publication (TD-P)

, and other related IRM policy requirements for mobile devices. (IRS-deﬁned) e. All IRS information and information systems. For information systems that store, process, or transmit, classiﬁed information, please refer to IRM
, Classiﬁed National Security Information (NSI) , for additional pro- cedures for protecting classiﬁed information. (

IRMs are developed in accordance with applicable laws, policies, federal regulations, Office of Management and Budget (OMB), Treasury Directives (TDs), National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) publications, and National Archieves and Records Administration (NARA). ) Government furnished and non-government furnished/personally owned mobile devices are vulnerable to theft and the loss of all data stored on them, which places the information they contain at risk of disclosure or compromise. Many theft rings operating today at airports, hotels, and other public places target mobile devices. Additionally, the use of mobile devices in public places (e.g., airports, restaurants, conferences, public transportation) and transmitting infor- mation through public telecommunications networks, presents a signiﬁcant of unauthorized persons observing and gaining access to the information that is being processed. Therefore, IRS employees, contractors, and volunteers shall abide by all requirements provided within this policy to help protect their government furnished and non-government furnished/personally owned mobile devices, and the information contained on them, from these risks. (

) The IRS has implemented the ″ Bring Your Own Device ″ (BYOD) program to permit IRS personnel to use non-government furnished/personally owned mobile devices for business purposes. This program offers the convenience using an approved non-government furnished/personally owned mobile device to access, process, transmit, or store IRS information. Therefore, those IRS employees who choose to participate in the program shall abide by the re- quirements speciﬁed within this policy. The IRS shall be able to ensure that agency data is protected at all places and all times. (
) Federal Information Processing Standard (FIPS)
mandates the use of NIST Special Publication (SP)
as an initial set of baseline security controls for the creation of agency IT security policy. (

) This IRM applies to all IRS information and systems, which include IRS pro- duction, development, test, and contractor systems. For systems that store, process, or transit classiﬁed national security information, refer to IRM
, Classiﬁed National Security Information , for additional procedures for protecting classiﬁed information. (

) The IRS shall ensure that: a. The product (e.g., software, hardware) and version selected are in accor- dance with IRS Enterprise Architecture (EA) Enterprise Standards Proﬁle (ESP) that dictates the official products and versions within the IRS; and b. The application or system version is a version for which the vendor still offers standardized technical support. (
) Security Requirements Checklists: a. Security Requirements Checklists (if accompanying this IRM) serve as the secure conﬁguration baseline and are developed in accordance with NIST SP

, National Checklist Program for IT Products: Guidelines for Checklist Users and Developers. b. IRMs with accompanying checklists contain a checklist with general security requirements (e.g., Defense Information System Agency (DISA) Security Requirements Guide (SRG)), as well as checklists with platform or technology speciﬁc requirements (e.g., Security Technical Implementa- tion Guides (STIGs), Center for Internet Security (CIS) Benchmarks). In the event a checklist is not available for a speciﬁc platform or technology, the general requirements checklist shall be used.

) This policy provides BYOD program participants with the Rules of Behavior that they shall abide by in order to prevent IRS data from being insecurely stored on a mobile device or carried over an insecure network where it could be subject to unauthorized access or disclosure. (
) The IRS shall ensure the application or system version is a version for which the vendor still offers standardized technical support. (
) In the event there is a discrepancy between this policy and IRM
, IRM
has precedence, unless the security controls/requirements in this policy are more restrictive or otherwise noted. (

) This IRM establishes the minimum baseline security policy and requirements for all IRS IT assets in order to: a. Protect the critical infrastructure, including government furnished and approved non-government furnished/personally owned mobile devices, and assets of the IRS against attacks that exploit IRS assets and other approved devices used to access, process, transmit or store IRS informa- tion. b. Enable government furnished and approved non-government furnished/ personally owned mobile devices that meet the security requirements this policy, to operate and support the business needs of the organiza- tion. c. Prevent unauthorized access to government furnished and approved government furnished/personally owned mobile devices when being to access, process, transmit or store IRS information. (
) It is acceptable to conﬁgure settings to be more restrictive than those deﬁned in this IRM. (
) To conﬁgure less restrictive controls requires a Risk-Based Decision (RBD). Refer to the Risk Acceptance and Risk-Based Decisions section within this IRM for additional guidance. (

) All IRS systems and applications shall be compliant with Executive Orders (E.O.s), OMB, Federal Information Security Modernization Act (FISMA), NIST, Department of Homeland Security (DHS), Treasury, and IRS guidelines as apply. (

.A tablet computer (tablet) is a mobile computer, larger than a mobile phone or mobile computing device , integrated into a ﬂat touchscreen and primarily operated by touching the screen rather than using a physical keyboard. A computer network that links two computers or devices through an underlying local or wide area network, while encapsulating the data and keeping it private. It is comparable to a pipe within a pipe. Even though the outer pipe contains the inner one, the inner pipe has a wall that blocks other traffic in the outer pipe from mixing with the inner traffic. To the rest of the network, the VPN traffic just looks like another traffic stream.
Links two or more devices using some wireless distribution method (typically spread
